inputs.text: But finding it wasn't enough, was it?
Oh no, finding it was just the beginning. Then came the engineering phase, and this is where Cosmos completely blew my mind.

For four days straight, I watched him collect materials. Coconut shell halves, smooth stones, broken coral fragments, even a bottle cap someone had littered. He'd carry three, sometimes four objects at once in his arms, bring them back, and arrange them with this obsessive precision.

Not just building - designing. Every shell was tested for fit. Every stone was positioned to create defensive barriers while maintaining escape routes. And here's the crazy part: one day I watched him pick up a rock, examine it with his suckers - which can taste and feel simultaneously, by the way - rotate it 180 degrees, and place it in a completely different location. Then he stepped back and looked at his work.
He revised his design! My research partner surfaced next to me and through our regulators she managed to say: Did that octopus just edit his architecture? And yes. Yes, he did.
